title: Represent Someone Who Died Qualifying Questions

pages.name: Qualifying Questions

elements.name: qualifyingIntroExplanation
elements.title:
A `Representation Grant` costs money and will take time to get. Don't waste time on this service if you don't need one.

For example, if the `deceased` had money in their bank account, that bank may give you that money to manage without a Representation Grant.

Different organizations have different policies to make sure that the right person gets the deceased's `assets`.

Ask each of the organizations that deal with the decased's assets if they will give you the asset without a Representation Grant (also known as a Grant of `Probate`). If an organization will not give you an asset, they will likely ask you to get a Representation Grant.

In addition, ask each of organizations that provided services to the deceased, (such as an electric company, phone company, credit card company, etc) if they will let you cancel the service without a Representation Grant.

elements.name: qualifyingNeedGrant
elements.title: Were you asked by an organization to get a `Representation Grant` (or a Grant of `Probate`)?
elements.description: This question is asking about organizations that hold the `deceased`'s `assets` or provided a serviced to the deceased.

elements.name: qualifyingNeedGrantNoExplanation
elements.title: If all of the organizations that hold the `deceased`'s `assets` simply gave you those assets to manage, then you probably don't need `Representation Grant`.

elements.name: qualifyingStillNeedGrant
elements.title: Do you still want to use this service to apply for a `Representation Grant`

elements.name: qualifyingStillNeedGrantNoError
elements.title:
It seems you don't need this service to manage the `deceased`'s `assets`.

The organizations that hold the the deceased's assets may ask you to sign a waiver in case there are problems in the future.

Once you have the assets, you are responsible for distributing them according to the law.

If the deceased made a `Will`, do your best to follow instruction in the Will on how to distribute the assets.

If the deceased did not make a Will, there are rules written in the Wills, Estates and Succession Act (WESA Part 3 Division 1) on how to distribute the assets. There are different rules depending on the deceased's family situation.

Read the rules written in WESA (Part 3 Division 1) here. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: qualifyingTempScopeExplanation
elements.title:
As of March 31, 2022, this service has only been developed for the first step in applying for a `Representation Grant`.

This service will:
  • Help an `applicant` create a Form P1 and send it to whoever is required to receive one.
  • Help the applicant create a Form P9 to show who they have given the P1 to whoever is required to receive one.

This service has only been developed for situations where:
  • Only a single person can is applying for the Representation Grant, and
  • You are either the spouse or child of the `deceased`, and
  • Each of the spouse(s) and children are alive, and
  • Each of the spouse(s) and children are adults (19 or older), and
  • Each of the spouse(s) and children are mentally competent (they can make decisions on their own), and
  • If the deceased owed more than $10,000 to a single person, that person needs to be alive, an adult and mentally competent, and
  • If someone gave you a citation (Form P32) that person needs to be alive, an adult and mentally competent.

elements.name: qualifyingTempScope
elements.title: Does the above situation match your situation?

elements.name: qualifyingTempScopeNoError
elements.title:
If the above conditions don't match your situation, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant` at this point in time.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations.

Please check later to see if this service has been developed for your specific situation. This service is continuously expanding to help more and more people.

In the mean time, the Government of British Columbia offers PDF forms that you may find helpful for your application. Click here to go to the forms. (This link opens in a new tab)

If you would like to be notified when new features are added to this service, click here to send an email to the Product Owner for this service ("Represent Someone Who Died").

elements.name: qualifyingRegisteredIndian
elements.title: Was the `deceased` a Registered Indian under the Government of Canada's Indian Act?
elements.description:
For more information about who is considered a Registered Indian, click here to go to the Government of Canada's Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The name of this act and its policies are not under the control of the Government of British Columbia.

elements.name: qualifyingRegisteredIndianEntitled
elements.title: Was the `deceased` entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act?
elements.description:
The deceased was entitled to be registered if at least one of the their parents is registered or entitled to be registered under section 6 of the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

If anyone in the deceased's immediate or extended family registered or entitled to be registered, it may mean the deceased was entitled to register as well.

elements.name: qualifyingRegisteredIndianReferredToBC
elements.title: Did Canada's Minister of Indigenous Services tell you to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a `Representation Grant` for the `deceased`?

elements.name: qualifyingRegisteredIndianYesExplanation
elements.title:
If the `deceased` was a Registered Indian and Canada's Minister of Indigenous Services did NOT tell you to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a Representation Grant, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant`.

According to the Government of Canada's Indian Act, Canada's Minister of Indigenous Services is the person in charge of choosing who will manage the belongings of a Registered Indian who has died.

For more information, click here to read Sections 42 to 45 about Descent of Property in the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The name of the Indian Act and its policies are not under the control of the Government of British Columbia. The Government of Canada's laws overpower the Government of British Columbia's laws and the Supreme Court of British Columbia's orders. The creators of this service apologize for the restrictions placed on you by the Indian Act.

elements.name: qualifyingRegisteredIndianEntitledNoExplanation
elements.title:
If the `deceased` was entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act and Canada's Minister of Indigenous Services did NOT tell you to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a Representation Grant, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant`.

According to the Government of Canada's Indian Act, Canada's Minister of Indigenous Services is the person in charge of choosing who will manage the belongings of someone who was entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act.

For more information, click here to read Sections 42 to 45 about Descent of Property in the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The name of the Indian Act and its policies are not under the control of the Government of British Columbia. The Government of Canada's laws overpower the Government of British Columbia's laws and the Supreme Court of British Columbia's orders. The creators of this service apologize for the restrictions placed on you by the Indian Act.

elements.name: qualifyingAfterWESAPanel
qualifyingDiedAfterWESA
elements.title: Did the `deceased` die after March 30, 2014?

elements.name: qualifyingDiedAfterWESANoError
elements.title:
At this point in time, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant` if the `deceased` died on March 30, 2014, or before.

The Wills, Estate and Succession Act became law on March 31, 2014. This service only supports the current laws.

If the deceased died before to the current Wills, Estate and Succession Act became law, your `application` also needs to comply with the old Estate Administration Act.

Please review both sets of laws to make sure your application will be successful.
  • the Estate Administration Act (This link opens in a new tab)
  • the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: qualifyingTermsPanel
qualifyingTerms
elements.title:
This service can help you apply for a `Representation Grant`. Before continuing, please read the terms for using this service.

"Represent Someone Who Died" is a service provided by the Government of British Columbia.

  • The Supreme Court of British Columbia will review the documents that you create through this service.
  • The Court may ask you for additional information even if you have used this service.
  • The Court will decide whether or not to give you a Representation Grant.
The Government of British Columbia may update this service at any time.

  • Learn more about the disclaimer and liability here. (This link opens in a new tab)
  • Learn more about privacy and security here. (This link opens in a new tab)
By clicking "Continue", you are agreeing to these terms.

elements.name: qualifyingComplicationsExplanationFutureScope
elements.title:
This service can help you apply for a `Representation Grant` whether the `deceased` made a `Will` or not.

At this point in time, this service has been developed for the most common situations.

If your situation is unusual, this service may still be able to help you. You will be able to ask the developer of this service if they can include your specific situation.

The next step is to create an account so that you can save your progress as you work through this service.
